awd_abstract_narration:
The National Nuclear Physics Summer School, held annually since 1988, is an effort by the nuclear physics community to acquaint students with the forefront issues of the field and with the experimental and theoretical methods available to nuclear physics researchers. The intent is to broaden student appreciation for and interest in the field, while also strengthening them technically. Typically most of the field's major directions are represented in the lectures: hot and cold nuclear matter, electromagnetic physics, weak interactions, astrophysics, and nuclear structure. Advanced graduate students and beginning postdoctoral researchers are the target audience. School organizers are charged with identifying outstanding lecturers from theory and experiment, conducting the school in a manner that encourages discussion and interaction, and developing supporting materials, including an online archive of lectures that can serve as a long-term reference for participating students and for others who are interested in the current status of nuclear physics. School organizers are assisted by the Principal Investigators and by a Steering Committee appointed by the Division of Nuclear Physics of the American Physical Society. 

The school is often the first opportunity for students to recognize the breadth of nuclear physics and to interact across subfields. As such, the National Nuclear Physics Summer School represents a community-building activity that provides students with excellent opportunities to interact with leading researchers in the field and to network with their peers. Students leave the school with stronger backgrounds in nuclear physics, and with new knowledge of their chosen specialties. As the lectures are preserved in an on-line archive, the students can return to this material when a need arises during their subsequent training and research. Students are given a chance to present talks and thus to gain experience in making presentations to a diverse audience.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the National Nuclear Physics Summer School from 2017 to 2023, an annual program that has been shaping the future of nuclear physics since 1988. Each year, around 50 advanced graduate students from all over the United States attend the school to learn from top researchers in the field. The aim of the school is to provide these students with a deeper understanding of the key scientific challenges in nuclear physics and the tools used to tackle them. It also helps build a community among young scientists by fostering connections and collaboration.

The school is overseen by a national Steering Committee, appointed by the Division of Nuclear Physics of the American Physical Society. To ensure accessibility for students nationwide, the school is hosted at a different university or research institution each year, covering various regions of the country. Since 2017, the NNPSS has been hosted by the following institutions:  University of Colorado, Boulder (2017), Yale University (2018), University of Tennessee, Knoxville (2019), Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2022), University of California, Riverside (2023), ensuring students from diverse geographical areas can participate. Due to travel restrictions during the COVID pandemic, the 2020 school was canceled and the 2021 school was hosted virtually jointly by Indiana University, Bloomington, and the National Autonomous University of Mexico.

Over the course of about 10 days, students attend lectures delivered by 12-15 leading experts in nuclear physics, covering both experimental and theoretical aspects of the field. These researchers are chosen not only for their expertise but also for their ability to engage and inspire the next generation of scientists. The schools adopted practices that ensured broad participation, and women scientists were well-represented among both the lecturers and the student participants. By making the lectures available online, the school provides a lasting resource for students and the broader nuclear physics community, extending the impact of the program far beyond the classroom.

The benefits of the summer school go beyond just learning from the experts. Students also have the chance to present their own research, sharpening their communication skills and receiving feedback from both peers and mentors. This interaction often sparks collaborations that extend well beyond the 10-day program, helping students build lasting professional relationships that will support their careers in the future. The program brings together students from different subfields of nuclear physics, which helps broaden their understanding of the field as a whole. It’s often the first opportunity for many students to connect with researchers working in areas outside of their specialization.

The summer school also plays an important role in promoting broader participation in nuclear physics. Outstanding students from underrepresented groups are encouraged to participate, and the program provides a supportive environment where they can network with their peers and mentors. This not only helps to build confidence but also ensures that a wider range of voices and perspectives are included in the future of nuclear research.

The impact of the school is significant. It strengthens students’ technical skills, boosts their confidence in presenting their research, and enhances their overall enthusiasm for nuclear physics. The relationships built during the school often result in ongoing collaborations that benefit both the students and the wider scientific community. While it is difficult to quantify the full impact of the program, the feedback from participants suggests that it plays a crucial role in preparing the next generation of nuclear physicists for the challenges ahead.

In conclusion, the National Nuclear Physics Summer School is an essential program for advancing nuclear research and training future scientists. By bringing together students and leading researchers, it creates an environment where young scientists can learn, collaborate, and grow. The program not only equips students with the knowledge and tools they need to succeed but also fosters a sense of community that will continue to shape the field for years to come.
